questions.text: A 30-year-old man is found unconscious in a closed garage with the car engine running. He is brought to the emergency department with severe headache, cherry-red discoloration of the skin, and altered sensorium. Pulse oximetry is falsely normal. Arterial blood gas shows normal PaO2. What type of hypoxia is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning leads to anaemic hypoxia by binding competitively and reversibly to hemoglobin, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb), which cannot carry oxygen.

  • CO has about 250 times higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen.
  • This reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood, even if PaOâ‚‚ remains normal.
  • Hence, tissue hypoxia occurs without an actual fall in oxygen tension-this defines anaemic hypoxia.

Although CO can inhibit cytochrome oxidase (a feature of histotoxic hypoxia), the predominant and primary mechanism in CO poisoning is anaemic hypoxia.

Explanation of other options:

Histotoxic hypoxia (Option B): Seen in cyanide poisoning, where oxygen delivery is normal but cells can't use it due to blocked electron transport chain.

Anoxic hypoxia (Option C): Results from inadequate oxygen in the environment or blocked airways-not the mechanism here.

Stagnant hypoxia (Option D): Due to reduced blood flow (e.g., shock, heart failure), which is not applicable in this context.

Key Takeaway:

Carbon monoxide poisoning primarily causes anaemic hypoxia by reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin.

questions.text: Lee Jones test is used to detect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lee Jones test is used to detect cyanide.

Lee Jones test:

  • To 5 ml of stomach contents add few crystals of ferrous sulphate and 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide.
  • Boil and cool and add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid.
  • Greenish-blue colour indicates cyanide, and purplish colour salicylates.

Explanation of other options:

Carbolic acid (Option A): Detected by ferric chloride test; produces violet coloration.

Arsenic (Option B): Detected by Reinsch's test or Marsh's test.

Lead (Option D): Detected by sodium sulfide or dithizone test.

Key Takeaway:

The Lee Jones test detects cyanide via greenish-blue color change in gastric contents after reacting with iron salts and acid.

questions.text: Mechanism of cyanide poisoning is by inhibiting:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mechanism of cyanide poisoning is by inhibiting Cytochrome oxidase

Action:

  • Cyanide inhibits the action of cytochrome oxidase, carbonic anhydrase and probably of other enzyme systems.
  • It blocks the final step of oxidative phosphorylation and prevents the formation of ATP and its use as energy source.
  • Cyanide acts by reducing the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood, and by combining with the ferric iron atom of intracellular cytochrome oxidase, preventing the uptake of oxygen for cellular respiration.
  • There is an interference with the intracellular oxidative processes in the tissues and it kills by creating histotoxic or cytotoxic anoxia, although the blood may contain a normal oxygen content.

Explanation of other options:

DNA synthesis (Option A): Not involved in cyanide toxicity; this is affected by agents like methotrexate.

Protein breakdown (Option C): Not inhibited; unrelated to cyanide mechanism.

Protein synthesis (Option D): Seen with toxins like diphtheria toxin or ricin-not cyanide.

Key Takeaway:

Cyanide causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase and halting cellular respiration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suspected cyanide poisoning in an industrial accident. The medical team initiates treatment with the standard cyanide antidote kit. Which of the following agents is NOT included in the standard cyanide antidote kit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard 3-step cyanide antidote kit contains:

  • Amyl nitrite (inhalation)
  • Sodium nitrite (IV)
  • Sodium thiosulfate (IV)

These work synergistically to detoxify cyanide by forming cyanmethemoglobin and converting it into thiocyanate, which is excreted via urine.

  • Amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite induce methemoglobinemia. Methemoglobin binds cyanide more avidly than cytochrome oxidase.
  • Sodium thiosulfate acts as a sulfur donor in the presence of the mitochondrial enzyme rhodanese, facilitating the conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate.

Sodium bicarbonate is not part of the standard cyanide antidote kit. It may be used for acidosis correction but has no direct role in cyanide detoxification.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

Explanation of other options:

Sodium thiosulfate (Option A): Sulfur donor; helps convert cyanide to thiocyanate.

Sodium nitrite (Option B): Produces methemoglobin which binds cyanide.

Amyl nitrite (Option D): First-line inhalational agent to induce rapid methemoglobinemia.

Key Takeaway:

Sodium bicarbonate is not a component of the cyanide antidote kit; it is only used for supportive correction of acidosis.

questions.text: Hyperbaric oxygen is given in the treatment of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy is used in the treatment of severe carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

CO has 210 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) and impairing oxygen delivery to tissues.

  • 100% oxygen reduces the half-life of COHb from ~5 hours (room air) to ~1 hour.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen (at 2-3 ATA pressure) further reduces COHb half-life to 20-30 minutes.
  • HBO also enhances mitochondrial function by reactivating cytochrome oxidase and prevents neurologic damage due to free radical injury.
  • HBO is especially indicated in:
    • COHb >25%
    • Loss of consciousness, seizures, coma
    • Pregnancy (even if COHb >15%)
    • Severe metabolic acidosis or cardiovascular instability

Explanation of other options:

Nerve gas (Option A): Treated with atropine, pralidoxime, not oxygen therapy.

CO2 poisoning (Option B): Managed by ventilatory support; HBO has no role.

HCN poisoning (Option C): Treated with cyanide antidote kit (amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, thiosulfate); HBO is not primary.

Key Takeaway:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated in severe carbon monoxide poisoning to rapidly dissociate CO from hemoglobin and reduce neurological sequelae.

questions.text: Signs and symptoms of CO poisoning starts when the concentration is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Signs and symptoms of CO poisoning starts when the concentration is >10%.

  • COHb levels above 3% to 4% in non-smokers and 10% in smokers are typically considered outside of normal limits.
  • Symptoms like mild headache, breathlessness starts above the level of 10% COHb.
  • Serious toxicity is associated with levels more than 25%.
  • Carbon monoxide poisoning may prove fatal above carboxyhaemoglobin levels of 60%.

Explanation of other options:

<10% (Option A): Usually does not cause symptoms; may be seen in smokers.

>20% (Option C): Causes moderate symptoms, but initial symptoms start at >10%.

>40% (Option D): Associated with severe toxicity, not the threshold for symptom onset.

Key Takeaway:

Symptoms of CO poisoning typically begin when COHb levels exceed 10%.
